data.title: Selection is not properly deleted in scene editor (master branch)
data.body:
@victorlevasseur There is a regression in master that looks related to `InitialInstancesContainer`. If you open a scene editor, select a bunch of objects with the mouse and then delete them, the wrong objects are deleted (some of the selection are still there, some that are not in the selection are deleted).

I've run a git bisect and [this commit](https://github.com/4ian/GD/commit/5aa30efa52fee08fd7e8c83be799cfa2eca841b8) introduces the bug:

```
~/Projects/F/GD   îˆ 5aa30ef... | bisect  git bisect bad
5aa30efa52fee08fd7e8c83be799cfa2eca841b8 is the first bad commit
commit 5aa30efa52fee08fd7e8c83be799cfa2eca841b8
Author: Victor Levasseur <victorlevasseur52@gmail.com>
Date:   Wed Sep 14 11:52:40 2016 +0200

    Improve InitialInstancesContainer code

    Add tests for InitialInstancesContainer

:040000 040000 48a593620e86b6fcb5dcd6f86c1002b6406a8e4f 45e0de8e566eed74c9d50b9327029720802a1aca M      Core
:040000 040000 9e6c6285f42856511097adbc80ed42c353b3a565 e28478af445080cfe17b656cc08fd966e04e4a46 M      GDCpp
:040000 040000 4a1781881815518823316f6cbf0a5d2008e0bec2 bb6f8cd47f4bd0ab4a2249c0d8d9c8b431a8822b M      IDE
```

I'm looking at the issue - maybe we could add a test for it once we have spotted the bug ;)

data.title: No shared_ptr for RuntimeObjects and SceneStack
data.body: **Needs heavy testing** as the debugger has been reworked not to use weak_ptr anymore (the debugger is now notified through ObjInstanceHolder when an instance is created or removed).

data.title: Manage gd::Object, gd::Layout, gd::ExternalEvents, gd::ExternalLayout and gd::SourceFile with std::unique_ptr
data.body:
I don't like `std::shared_ptr` used for everything ^^ (make C++ look Java-ish).

PS : same thing coming soon for GDCpp (the debugger needs some rework but is not enough to justify the use of `std::shared_ptr`).

data.title: Fix array deleted with delete instead of delete[]

data.title: Fix code generation when multiple scenes link to the same events
data.body:
This fixes a bug when multiple scenes are linking to the scenes events.
During code generation, events can be modified, for example to include links or to erase the type of conditions/actions that are not valid (when using an non existing object for example). 
For the Javascript platform, when generating code for a scene, the same events were used for generating the code of the next scene.
If both scene were using the same events, and that code generation made changes to the events for the first one (for example, to remove an action due to a missing object), the second scene would also be impacted by the change (for example, the action for the object won't be generated).

I stumbled on this bug while using two scenes with the same events, but not the same objects.
With the fix, events are copied so we are sure that code generation is not modifying them, as one could expect when using the code generation functions.

cc @victorlevasseur For your interest :)

data.title: Feature/inventory
data.body:
This includes a new small extension to store an inventory with items in memory, to avoid re-implementing this classic game element by hand using events. Items number can be limited, unlimited, marked as equipped.

The PR also includes a few improvements to the JS game engine to avoid garbage creation and fix compilation on OS X 10.11 ("El Capitan").

data.title: Optimize Hitboxes collision testing for "big" objects
data.body:
"big" = objects with a lot of hitboxes.
# What is the optimization ?

This PR adds a new `GetHitboxes(sf::FloatRect hint)` overload to `RuntimeObject` to get Hitboxes with a AABB hint. 

However the object is not required to follow the hint: it just needs to return at least the hitboxes intersecting the AABB (the default implementation only forwards the call to the standard `GetHitboxes()` method).

This new method is used by `RuntimeObject::IsCollidingWith` (so it also works for the Platformer behavior :) ) and `RuntimeObject::SeparateFromObjects`.
# Which object uses this new overload ?

The only object currently taking advantage of the hint is the `TileMapObject` as it contains `TileCountX` \* `TileCountY` hitboxes causing poor performances when using all the hitboxes. This object now get only the hitboxes of the tiles with the AABB hint.
# Performances

Obviously, this brings a **huge** performance improvement when testing the collisions with a TileMapObject or having a TileMapObject as a platform:
- before this optimization: big FPS drop (~30-50 fps) fps with a 500*300 tilemap and a single colliding object !
- after this optimization: almost no FPS loss (~180-200 fps) when testing or not the collision between an object and a tilemap (same applies to the PlatformerBehavior)
# A testcase

I made a small testcase to test some scenarios with the new system. You can test the project with the current GDevelop version and this version to see the difference : 
[hitbox-optimization-testcase.zip](https://github.com/4ian/GD/files/425384/hitbox-optimization-testcase.zip)
(forgot to update the images filepath, but they are in the .zip)

data.title: Import multiple images
data.body:
Hello, 

The ability to import multiple images on a 'sprite' and then allow it to be renamed picture by picture or allow to develop. If the developer choose not to rename all the images the engine could name in a numerical sequence.

Thanks!!

data.title: Feature/linkevent
data.body:
- New editor the the link event
- Fix the bug with external events when the link only includes some events
- Deprecate the "link only events from X to X position" feature (only available for "old" link events)
- Link events can now include an events group (by name) of a layout/external events. If multiple group events have the same name, a warning is displayed and only the first one is included

Tested with simple testcases. But still need to be tested on bigger projects.

data.title: Pathfinding behavior : the real size not taken into account
data.body: Even if the object is resized, the "Obstacle" behavior still take its original size into account.

data.title: Pathfinding behavior : bad movement if origin is not at the top-left corner
data.body: The object (sprite) is brutally moved by the offset between the top-left corner and its real origin point when starting moving.

data.title: Frequent crashes with only small changes
data.body:
I am running GD on a Linux Mint 18.0 machine. I get frequent crashes when I make small changes such as adding or deleting a condition. I've gone so far as to build GD from source to see if I could track the issues down. 
I've filled out the "Something bad happened" dialog window with as much information as I can (including an error dump since I launch from terminal to try and see what is causing crashes), Anyway, this "Something bad happened" seems to me to be a bit of a black hole for reporting. Should I post issues here instead?

Sometimes GD just segfaults and that is near impossible to track down. But sometimes I get a more meaningful crash report in terminal. GD knows when it crashes obviously, what would be useful is to know in what module it crashed in and an approx line number. I'm a bit rusty with c++ but I may be able to figure things out to help.

data.title: Implement AnchorBehavior for the Javascript Platform
data.body:
This is a port of the AnchorBehavior for the Javascript platform.

@victorlevasseur You can take a look if you wish :)

data.title: Retrieve number of subitems from variable/structure (native/js)
data.body:
- global variables (expression)
- scene variables  (expression)
- object variables (expression)

data.title: Release a small bugfix version for Windows only
data.body: A lot of users currently have problems with the manifest (they can't edit the text objects and some can't open a scene without a crash).

data.title: Feature/anchor behavior
data.body: This PR adds an **Anchor behavior** that can anchor the object's edges to the window's bounds.

data.title: Texture loading optimization
data.body: Optimize the textures loading by avoiding a `sf::Texture` copy and a `sf::Image` copy. As these two classes don't have a move ctor (and not even an implicit one), use references to load the image (and not a return value).

data.title: Some fixes for GCC6 and Fedora 24
data.body:
Add the missing GLU include.

Need to be tested on other OSes (Windows and MacOS).
